Wish You Were Here: Vacation tips from fellow travelers Bay Area News Group readers Posted: 10/14/2015 03:00:00 PM PDT Updated: 10/16/2015 01:27:04 PM PDT PERU: Gale and Paula Ensign, of Saratoga, are just back from a visit to Machu Picchu. The mysterious remains of the Inca civilization that disappeared so long ago was the highlight of a three-week trip that also included Lake Titicaca in Bolivia and the Galápagos Islands in Ecuador, Paula says. (Courtesy of the Ensign Family) Courtesy of the Ensign Family PERU: Gale and Paula Ensign, of Saratoga, are just back from a visit to Machu Picchu. "The mysterious remains of the Inca civilization that disappeared so long ago were the highlight of a three-week trip that also included Lake Titicaca in Bolivia and the Galápagos Islands in Ecuador," Paula says. "Our Cuzco-born Peruvian guide, Ruben, shared his wealth of knowledge of the Incas. We booked our trip with Overseas Adventure Travel, who supplied all of our transportation, accommodations, guides and most meals, including a home-hosted lunch featuring local dishes." NORWAY: Alamo residents Tom and Melva Hansen (standing) and Danville residents Bernie and Jean Elissagaray are just back from a trip to ports in Iceland, England, Russia, Sweden and Norway, which included a stop in Geirangerfjord, Norway, where they took pictures with a new friend. The troll, Jean says, is a myth to the people of Norway. (Courtesy of the Elissagaray Family) 
Travel tips: It's important that travelers understand the physical requirements a trip to Machu Picchu entails, "such as the ability to climb many steps without handrails to access the Inca ruins, and being able to tolerate altitudes up to 11,000 feet. Walking sticks were available at reasonable prices in Peru, and we brought with us altitude sickness medicine which we obtained from our HMO." Courtesy of the Elissagaray Family NORWAY: Alamo residents Tom and Melva Hansen (standing) and Danville residents Bernie and Jean Elissagaray are just back from a trip to ports in Iceland, England, Russia, Sweden and Norway. In Geirangerfjord, Norway, they took pictures with a new friend. "The troll," Jean says, "is a myth to the people of Norway." Advertisement 
Travel tip: "Take plenty of warm clothes," Jean says, when visiting points this far north, where the weather never turns balmy. Courtesy of the Suri Family ARGENTINA: Sunnyvale's Suri family -- Mahesh, Aman, Rovina and Aneka -- are just back from a South American trek that included Argentina's Iguazu Falls and Brazil's Sugarloaf Mountain, in Rio de Janeiro. "Iguazu Falls are considered one of the new wonders of the world and rightfully so. The falls are spectacular!" Rovina says. "There are more than 270 falls in an area where cliffs and islets are scattered in a half moon." 
Travel tips: At Iguazu, "you can walk around trails or (ride) a picturesque train. There are two basic circuits: an upper path and a lower path. The Argentine government has done a fantastic job of building pedestrian bridges that allow people to cross over the small falls that are created by the big falls. I would highly recommend staying at the park, rather than in the town of Iguazu, since you can walk to the park at any time. There are lots of monkeys, anteaters, colorful birds and butterflies at the park. There is also a canteen where one can eat." Share your travels with us! Send your recent vacation selfies to jburrell@bayareanewsgroup.com . Be sure to tell us who's who, where they're from and where you are -- and include a couple of travel tips to help fellow readers globetrot too.
